title: Global Oil Prices Plunge 2% as Trump De-escalates Iran Tensions
text:
Thursday, 15 January 2026 , 11:36 AM
Global oil prices witnessed a significant decline on Thursday, January 15, 2026, with both major benchmarks dropping by more than 2% in a single session.
This reversal ended a multi-day rally that had been driven by fears of a military conflict in the Middle East.
Here are the primary factors contributing to the price drop:
Easing Tensions with Iran
The most immediate driver was a shift in rhetoric from US President Donald Trump. Earlier in the week, prices surged as the US administration threatened military action and 25% tariffs on countries doing business with Tehran following the violent crackdown on protesters in Iran.
However, on Wednesday afternoon, President Trump stated he had received assurances that the killing of protesters had stopped and suggested he might hold off on military strikes for now. This eased "risk premiums" that traders had baked into the price, leading to a swift sell-off.
Surge in US Oil Inventories
Data released by the Energy Information Administration (EIA) on Wednesday showed a much larger-than-expected build-up of US crude oil and gasoline stocks.
Resumption of Venezuelan Exports
Following the recent regime change in Caracas and the ouster of Nicolás Maduro, the new transitional government has begun releasing stranded oil.
Broader 2026 Supply Surplus Forecasts
Long-term forecasts continue to weigh on the market. Both the EIA and Goldman Sachs have projected that global oil production will exceed demand throughout 2026.
Experts predict that Brent crude could average as low as $56 per barrel this year due to rising production in the US and the return of sanctioned oil to the global market.
